title.narrative: PEAR+3 - Participatory and Empowering community-based Approaches for Resilience

description.narrative:
PEAR Plus 3 is a multi-sectorial programme planned by UNICEF in three provinces in eastern DRC; North Kivu, South Kivu and the former Province Orientale. The objective is to strengthen the resilience amongst populations to deal with recurring crises and conflicts through increasing access to basic social services and creating local sustainable community structures. This is done by developing platforms for dialogue and reconciliation, so called Chikembes, where joint action plans and decisions on the local community's future are discussed and adopted. The target group consists of both returnees and host communities, approximately 300,000 people in 100 villages.
The programme is built on seven pillars:
1. Education: The education interventions will revolve around peace building capacity building for teachers, students and local authorities. It will furthermore improve access to quality education through cash transfers to schools, capacity building of teachers in various Peacebuilding Education and Advocacy (PBEA) modules and improving the governance of schools
2. Health: Provision of vaccinations, equipment, medicines, training of health staff etc.
3. WASH: Provision of technical and logistical support to schools and communities in the 7 step model to reach healthy village’s certification. Strengthening of capacity on WASH to various stakeholders.
4. Child Protection: This will be done through four channels; childhood hub (discussion groups, schools, child reporters), parental hub (mobilising parents for inter-generational exchange), community hub (health actors, police) and state hub (including the Division of Social Affairs).
5. Community Mobilisation: advocacy, social mobilisation, social/behavourial change, capacity building etc.
6. Social protection systems: cash-based programming (unconditional or soft conditioning).
7. Socio-economic reintegration (training, education, vocational training, support, cash transfer etc.) focusing on women and youth. The creation of Chikembes is key to the success of PEAR Plus concept and can also be seen as a result in itself. Chikembes builds on an inclusive and broad participation of women, men, boys and girls where everyone's voice are heard. In addition to being a democratic institution, the Chikembe is a platform for peace building were disputes - often on the use of land - discussed which prevents conflict to arise. Chikembes contributes to social cohesion, with clear common goals for the community.
Sweden has previously provided support for phase one and two of the PEAR Plus programme in DRC with good results. This proposed third phase, the four-year program is estimated at 87 million SEK.

Participatory and Empowering community-based Approaches for Resilience – Phase 3 (PEAR Plus 3), UNICEF, 2015-2019, 87 MSEK
PEAR Plus 3 är ett multisektoriellt program genom UNICEF i tre provinser i östra DRK; Nordkivu, Sydkivu och f.d. Province Orientale. Syftet är att stärka motståndskraften hos befolkningen att hantera återkommande kriser och konflikter genom att öka tillgången till grundläggande sociala tjänster samt skapa lokala hållbara samhällsstrukturer. Detta görs genom att utveckla plattformar för dialog och försoning, s.k. Chikembes, där gemensamma handlingsplaner och beslut om lokalsamhällets framtid diskuteras och antas. Målgruppen består av såväl återvändande flyktingar som mottagande samhällen, ca 300.000 personer i 100 byar.
Aktiviteter kommer att genomföras inom sju områden: 1. Utbildning: Stärkt grundutbildning till barn genom kontantöverföring till skolor och kapacitetshöjande insatser för lärare, samt utbildning i fredsbyggande till elever, lärare, lokala myndigheter och mottagarsamhällena. 2. Hälsa: Vaccinationer, utrusning, mediciner, kapacitethöjande åtgärder till sjukvårdpersonal etc. 3. Vatten & sanitet (WASH): Tekniskt och logistiskt stöd till skolor och samhällen inom sju-stegsmodellen för att nå ”hälsosam by”-status. 4. Skydd/protection: Fyra nivåer (hubbar) av skyddsmekanismer kommer skapas: barnen själva (diskussionsgrupper, skolor, barnreportar), föräldrar (generationsöverskridande utbyte), samhällsfunktioner (hälsoaktörer, polis) samt lokala myndigheter. 5. Social sammanhållning: Gemensamma påverkansaktiviteter, insatser för att ändra normer/attityder etc. 6. Sociala skyddsnät: Kontantöverföring (utan villkor eller ”mjukt villkorat”) 7. Socio-ekonomisk återintegrering: Utbildning, yrkesutbildning, inkomstskapande aktiviter, primärt riktat till kvinnor och unga.
Sverige har tidigare gett stöd till fas ett och två av PEAR Plus med goda resultat. Denna tredje föreslagna fas är ett fyra-årigt program som beräknas uppgå till 87 MSEK.

description.narrative: PEAR, as designed, aims to support a promising environment that is resilient to human development in contexts of chronic conflict by improving the resilience of communities through the provision of social services supplemented by activities designed to improve social reintegration; strengthen social cohesion; and improve community capacities to reduce and manage inter and intra-community conflicts as well as to negotiate a safe space. This contribution during this fourth year of implementation has succeeded in producing the following results: - In Education: In North Kivu province 1,400 school children enhanced their capacity in peace building through training in peace and 1,762 out of school children were prepared for school reintegration through catch classes organised during summer holidays. 300 adolescents, of which 92 were reached during the reporting period, were enrolled in vocational training centers. - In Health-Nutrition: the treatment of over Severe Acute Malnutrition in the affected health zones reached 2,730 suffering from SAM. In WASH: 169 healthy villages and 34 healthy schools were supported by PEAR+ during the post certification process to maintain their status as healthy villages and schools. - In Child Protection: 1,515 children benefited from birth registration services through mass campaigns activities. - 804 households received cash assistance, which were primarily used to purchase essential household goods, access to shelter and primary health care. - 1,461 adolescents were trained on sensitization techniques about child protection risk during conflict and post-conflict situations. - 75 gender champions were selected in Ituri and North Kivu to promote a more comprehensive understanding of gender vulnerabilities and needs. Despite these significant progresses, this reporting period was characterized by four main challenges i) volatile security situation ii) Ebola outbreak in affected areas iii) change of implementing consortium and iv) resilience operational research. Overall, these challenges delayed the implementation of activities in North Kivu and Ituri province. The CARE consortium operating in North Kivu has faced significant challenges in program implementation, therefore in April 2019, UNICEF transferred the lead and implementation of activities to the Adventist Development and Relief Agency (ADRA) consortium in North Kivu province.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
